job_title: Sr. Software Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros:
I have over 20 years of software development experience, and I have worked at many different companies on many projects. And I will say without hesitation that the working environment at the Church is the best anywhere I have been as a software engineer. We rarely work more than a 40-hour work week (occasional, but rare emergencies might be the exception). The management stresses it - they truly want us to work an eight-hour day and then go home to be with our families. It's wonderful. 

Yes, bureaucracy, politics, etc. exist at the Church like anywhere else. But it is far less than most other places in my opinion. Almost everyone is simply trying to do the right thing most of the time while putting team needs and the purpose of the Church ahead of personal egos, self-centered views, etc. Agile and software development processes, while not perfect (it never is), and it varies from project to project, are for the most part what they should be: team-focused (without ignoring individual needs/wants), light-weight, flexible, and the teams are allowed to be self-organizing - more so than anywhere else I have worked. The net result is a much more productive work environment. I can get double the amount of work done in a 40-hour week at the Church than I could somewhere else in a 60-hour week. Everywhere else I have worked in Corporate America stifles productivity/innovation with their never-ending focus on heavy-weight Agile nonsense (SAFe anyone?) and Agile dogma. This is nothing more than inefficient waterfall processes that are wrapped in an Agile label so that the executives feel good about "doing Agile". Not at the Church - these things are done the way they were intended to be (with minimal exceptions here and there.) 

Training is good, as long as there is budget for it, which there usually is. The technology stack is good - not always "bleeding edge", but they try to keep up for the most part. 

It is interesting to work on projects that give me a greater understanding of the Church's purpose and inner, organizational way of doing things. Working on projects that I feel a strong sense of purpose enhances the productivity, and enjoyment of work. 

Working remotely is the preferred way of working for IT professionals at the Church - although some people work in the office, most work from home. Video chatting/working with other team members is efficient and works well. Most teams have occasional team activities and occasional in-office team meetings to ensure that team members see each other face-to-face on occasion. 

The benefits are good. Health insurance (DMBA) has many options with low monthly premiums and no deductibles for in-network healthcare. (One negative side effect of this is the lack of health savings accounts - low deductible plans are not available for this. There are the FSA health savings spending accounts available, however.) Low co-pays also. Dental insurance is good also. 

Vacation/sick leave are excellent. I never have a problem requesting vacation time. 

Retirement benefits are very good. They have a 4-percent 401K match and an 8-percent additional that you are just gifted. Not much beats that.
cons:
Salary might be a little below the norm - but with recent salary adjustments, they are trying to address this so that pay is closer to the mean. Obviously, no bonuses, or other cash incentives. 

None of the many perks that you might get at another tech company. 

Computer equipment is average at best. 

It can be difficult to get a full-time position. I had to be a contractor for a while before a full-time position opened up. 

Really, there isn't much to add here - I am stretching to find many "cons".

Organization is reluctant to move toward flex time or telecommuting or other nontraditional approaches. Organization is extremely male-centric (probably north of 90 percent) in leadership positions at the managing director and director levels, though that seems to be changing a bit. Could do better at promoting people from within.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT

review_title: Be careful what department you go and work for.

We spend tons of time and money training them and incorporating them into critical roles, and then we let them go when their contract expires.

There is still enormous ambiguity around the most recent initiative to reorganize and simplify. And there is still a feeling that the old "regime" is mostly still in place.

People see that certain managers bounce around from position to completely unrelated position about every year, and they aren't leaving wild successes in their wake. At best, they seem to be average managers. What are employees supposed to think when there are free spirits who can apparently change their job whenever they feel like it, but they are always involved in high level initiatives and discussions? There is a feeling of favoritism, and if you're not on the list, you'll never make very high.

The way finances in the department are handled is messy, time consuming, and difficult. Financial information is almost always out of date, yet finance is always asking employees for more and more work to make their lives easier, rather than the other way around. We waste tons of time tracking and then approving billable hours.

The listing here on Glassdoor is terribly misleading. Every department is wildly different in how it is run and its goals and management. President Nelson has very little to do with the day-to-day work of most departments, so rating him gives a skewed impression of the workplace.

I could go on and on, but I'll cut this short here.

People often don't like talking about these events at the church office because it often affects others negatively and impacts their view of the church, but this isn't uncommon. job_title: Customer Service Representative: IT Support in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are a few pros. Number one being the benefits package. The benefits package is one of the best in the market! And that's why people stay. The location is also nice. It's close to trax and the frontrunner. Last but not the least, I really liked working with people who shared the same values as me.
cons:
There are so many more downsides than there are pros. First, there are no opportunities for advancement.  I've been here for almost five years and I'm in the same position as when I started and it's not like I don't try. I've applied many, many times. Second, the corporate culture is something to frown upon. If you don't fit the typical Utah Mormon mold, best of luck to you.  Prepare for some scrutiny. There's no professional development here. Also, they don't offer any onsite perks. You just work, work, work, work, and work. Management also never shows appreciation for their employees. There is NO autonomy and you are not allowed to make your own decisions. Your breaks are timed and if you go over just ONE MINUTE, you'll be reported. If you go on the internet while on your shift, you will be reported. They also keep track of how much time you spend off the phones. If you're not busy enough, they'll give you a "Subject Matter Expert TASK" like training other people, doing quality assurance on calls, writing instructions (technical writing) but for no additional pay. BUT, taking calls is your FIRST priority. There is no sort of flexibility in your schedule. You are expected to live and breathe work. 

There's an overwhelming amount of things to do on a day-to-day basis.

But perhaps the most disappointing thing about this place is, they don't practice what they preach. Employees are expected to treat work like church and are expected to "lead like the savior," but management treats us all like we're disposable. The turnover here is quite high, because if you had other options, why would you stay in a place that makes you feel like you're nothing? The people who end up staying are those who have no other choice. This place doesn't tend to keep "the best" talent. Instead, it tends to keep those who have nowhere else to go--which says a lot about the corporate culture they've cultivated here.
